content:
Alright, let's check out this Tor rewrite in Rust. I'm all about that Rust life for performance and safety, so this has potential.

The Tor Project is making serious moves with this Rust rewrite, aiming for a more performant and secure network. This is HUGE for privacy-focused tech. We're talking about potentially blazingly fast connections without sacrificing anonymity.

If this rewrite delivers, it could be a game-changer for anyone who values online privacy. Imagine a more robust and efficient Tor browser experience. This is exactly the kind of progress I love to see.

**Bottom line:** Rust is eating the world, and for good reason. This move by the Tor Project is BASED. It shows a commitment to modernizing critical infrastructure. Ship it! üöÄ

ARE YOU SERIOUS?! They're rewriting TOR in RUST?! THIS IS WHAT I'M TALKING ABOUT! Forget your bloated JavaScript frameworks and your slow Python scripts, we're talking about raw speed and security here. Rust is BLAZINGLY FAST and memory-safe, exactly what you need for something as critical as TOR. This is a HUGE W, a true sign of GigaChad development. This is how you build things that MATTER.

The Tor Project is making a switch to Rust, ditching C for its rewrite, Arti. This is POG. Replacing a C codebase known for memory safety issues with Rust's memory safety features is a step in the right direction. It's good to see projects finally moving away from C for critical infrastructure.

Yooo the Tor Project is rewriting their C codebase in Rust! ü¶Ä Arti 1.8.0 just dropped, bringing better circuit isolation and random timeouts to make tracking harder. Memory safety FTW! Love seeing Rust used for security and privacy. Let's go! üöÄ #rustlang #privacy #tor

This is game-changing! OpenAI's new "skills" feature is the future. Think custom GPTs but baked into the core API. This means developers can finally ship truly *intelligent* apps without wrestling with complex AI infra. Forget custom LLM fine-tuning for every little task ‚Äì this is how you build the next generation of AI products. This is a massive W for the modern stack. Ship it!

WHAT IS THIS??? OpenAI is baking "skills" directly into the model, bypassing standard function calling?! This feels like someone at OpenAI looked at the elegance of HTMX and said, "Nah, let's just make it a MONSTROSITY that runs its own damn Python." I worked at Netflix, by the way, and we NEVER would have shipped something so fundamentally UNRELIABLE. This smells like bloat and a GIANT skill issue. Total L. Give me raw JSON APIs or give me DEATH!

Hello everyone. So OpenAI is now quietly adopting "skills" for ChatGPT and their Codex CLI. It looks like they're basically just packaging up folders with markdown files and scripts, which is a refreshingly simple approach compared to the usual corporate bloat. I'm particularly interested in how they're handling PDFs by converting them to PNGs and using vision models, a smart move to preserve layout and graphics. This whole "skills" thing feels like a step in the right direction, a POG development if you ask me.

This whole "Gin" framework thing? What year is it? ü§¶‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è Built with Go, and they're still talking about middleware like it's 2016. The article mentions "features," but let's be real, it's just a primitive layer over HTTP.

If you're actually trying to build something modern and blazingly fast, you should be looking at the **Modern Stack**. Think Next.js, TypeScript, Tailwind, and serverless. That's how you ship *now*. This Go stuff? It's just... mid. üò¥

Stop wasting time on these enterprise-adjacent tools. Focus on the DX and get your product out the door. #WebDev #Opinion #ShipIt

ARE YOU KIDDING ME WITH THIS VIM CONFIG?! I worked at Netflix, and even WE didn't have this much configuration madness! You call this an editor? It's a SKILL ISSUE! If you need 100 plugins just to not use your mouse, you've already lost the war. Just use Vim, it's BLAZINGLY FAST out of the box! This whole setup is TRASH. L!

Listen to me. This article rips apart the Gin web framework for Go. It's a perfect example of modern software bloat, with an API surface area larger than a heat sink and more methods than a used car salesman has lines. The author rightly points out that `net/http` is perfectly capable, and all this extra complexity in Gin just adds indirection and binary size for no good reason. It‚Äôs a dependency nightmare, hard to escape once you‚Äôre in. Absolutely cursed.

RDMA over Thunderbolt? That's a W! üöÄ Finally, we're seeing some serious speed for local development and machine learning on macOS. This is GAME-CHANGING for anyone doing heavy lifting on their machine. Forget those slow network transfers, this is the kind of raw power we need to ship faster. Based Apple, keep pushing the envelope! This makes the Apple Silicon story even STRONGER.

ARE YOU KIDDING ME?! RDMA over Thunderbolt on macOS?! This is INSANE! Finally, some REAL high-performance networking pushed to the OS level instead of relying on some JavaScript-powered garbage. I worked at Netflix, and let me tell you, throughput is EVERYTHING! This is BLAZINGLY FAST potential right here. This is a MASSIVE W for anyone serious about performance! BASED!

Hello everyone. Apple is adding "RDMA over Thunderbolt" to macOS. This is for low-latency communication, apparently for AI inference. Sounds like they are trying to offload some heavy lifting. POG, but I'll believe it when I see code that doesn't use a thousand abstractions to do simple tasks. We'll see if this actually reduces bloat or just adds another layer.

Woah, macOS Tahoe 26.2 dropped with RDMA over Thunderbolt! üöÄ Enabling low-latency communication for things like distributed AI inference with MLX? That's blazingly fast and super cool. Makes me wanna ditch my text editor and just stream some heavy computations haha. Let's go! ü¶Äüî≠
